page.title: 09Rural Scenery:Chinnor etc
page.content: The landscape of numerous hedged fields with occasional clumps of trees presents a typical English scene. A gentle slope from Chinnor leads to a mostly flat and low lying area. The lowest point in our designated area is marked at 78 metres A.S.L. and the highest is 116 metres. The soil is strong clay and the lowest point of the Chinnor-Thame Road frequently floods. This road carries relatively light traffic and vehicles have little visual impact. Buildings are predominantly of brick and stone with tiled roofs. Some of the older buildings are thatched. Chalk hills have provided the flint often found in village cottages. Many houses date back to mediaeval times. Large modern estates are found in Chinnor.
